title: On the Thermal Stability of a New Metastable D022 Cr3Ni Intermetallic Within High-temperature Cr-based Alloys
content: Interest in Cr-based alloys between the 1950s – 1970s as a higher temperature alternative to Ni-based superalloys, first stemmed from the its increased melting point and thermal conductivity [1–4]. Unfortunately, pure Cr suffers from poor room temperature ductility and formability, with early attempts at improving the ductility of Cr-based alloys included alloying additions like Re (up to 40 at%) proved to be cost-prohibitive [5] – limiting scalability and widespread adoption. However, as the temperature limits of current Ni-based superalloys are reached, there has been renewed interest in the development of new (and ductile) Cr-based alloys for next generation aerospace and energy generation applications [6–8].
